Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a pivotal technology for sustainable production of chemicals from non-fossil resources. However, the design of catalysts to tailor product distribution, particularly to enhance olefin selectivity, remains an enduring challenge. Herein, we report an iron-based catalyst modified with oxygen-containing groups, Fe3O4/HEC (hydroxyethyl group-modified), which demonstrates extraordinary catalytic performance in FTS without any alkali metal promoters. This catalyst exhibits high activity, achieving 41.36 % light olefin (C2-C4 =) selectivity and an O/P ratio of 5.49. Meanwhile, the C5 + hydrocarbon selectivity reaches 40.38 % (with 68.2 % linear α-olefins). The modified catalyst promotes the formation of iron carbides and facilitates the coupling of *CHx to promote chain growth while suppressing secondary hydrogenation reactions, which is considered to account for the high selectivity toward olefins and heavy hydrocarbons. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO hydrogenation Surface modification Iron-based catalysts Linear α-olefin selectivity Reaction pathway Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) stands as a cornerstone heterogeneous catalytic process for converting syngas into premium hydrocarbons and chemicals [1,2]. This technology alleviates dependence on finite fossil fuels and curbs air pollution from conventional petroleum refining [3,4]. With the international community's intensifying focus on energy security and climate action, this process takes on strategic importance [5–7]. It is well established that Fe, Co, Ni and Ru can catalyze the FTS reaction, with each exhibiting distinct catalytic behaviors [8]. Among these, Fe-based catalysts are regarded as more promising than Ni, Co or Ru based catalysts in FTS, due to their lower cost, high olefin selectivity, superior tolerance to different H2/CO ratios and resistance to syngas impurities [9]. Olefins serve as pivotal chemical feedstocks. The production of olefins through FTS technology has received much attention, leveraging its advantages in catalyst selectivity, feedstock adaptability, and process economy. However, FTS reactions are complex as multiple reaction pathways coexist and compete dynamically, leading to diverse products [10–13]. Thus, the rational design and synthesis of novel catalysts to regulate the product distribution are the key to FTS technology. Currently, research on Fe-based catalysts primarily focuses on three key aspects: modification of metal promoters, design of novel supports, and modulation of the chemical environment surrounding active sites. In general, alkali metals and manganese can enhance olefin selectivity [14]. However, catalyst stability deteriorates due to the loss of alkali metal promoters and carbon deposition [15]. When employed as a promoter in FTS, Mn significantly influences the catalyst phase composition [16]. Literature has demonstrated that due to the strong bonding between Fe and Mn, the formation of iron carbides is inhibited [17]. This inhibition is disadvantageous for maintain catalytic activity. The design of novel supports and catalyst surface modification can also significantly improve the catalytic performance. Bang et al. [46] reported Fe-based catalysts supported on polyaniline (PANI), in which the nitrogen functional groups facilitated the dispersion and carbonization of Fe. Notably, catalysts without additional promoters exhibited high CO conversion and C2-C4 olefin selectivity. Li et al. [20] designed a surface-modified g-C3N4 supported Fe-based catalyst, in which the modification enabled precise tuning of surface functional groups and electronic effects. This strategic modification effectively tailored the product distribution in FTS. Moreover, catalytic reactions require moderate adsorption of reactants and intermediates and rapid desorption of products [18,19]. Modulating the surface environment of the catalyst can improve the product distribution. Gao et al. introduced polar liquids (PEG 400, PEG 600, 1,4-Butanediol and glycol) into a slurry bubble reactor, a strategy that facilitated the rapid desorption of products and significantly enhanced the α-olefin selectivity to over 70 % [21]. Shi et al. devised Ru-based amphiphilic nanohybrid catalysts, conducting the reaction in a batch reactor where olefins formed in the aqueous phase diffused into the oil phase. This phase transfer mechanism significantly mitigated secondary reactions of olefins [22]. Nonetheless, these strategies often necessitate the addition of auxiliary solvents, and the concomitant complexity of the reaction system precludes their applicability to continuous industrial production. Group modification of the catalyst surface to enhance target product selectivity, achieved by introducing nitrogen or oxygen-containing functional groups to alter reactant adsorption energy barriers and the desorption kinetics of products, is considered a more straightforward and efficient approach. In our previous work, the hydroxyethyl cellulose-modified Fe-based catalyst exhibited remarkable olefin selectivity. However, its CO conversion was only 8.8 % [23]. It is demonstrated that hydroxyl groups adsorb water molecules, promoting the formation of *CH2 intermediates. Concurrently, the hydrophilic surface accelerates olefin desorption by reducing adsorption energy, thereby enhancing olefin selectivity through suppressed hydrogenation side reactions. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that surface OH* coverage significantly lowers the activation energy for C-C coupling, thereby enhancing the selectivity toward olefins [24]. This theoretical insight underscores the critical role of hydroxyl groups. Nonetheless, given the intricate molecular architecture of organic polymers, the specific mode of action and underlying mechanisms through which carbon-oxygen functional modifiers govern FTS product selectivity remain poorly understood. In this work, Fe-based catalysts modified with oxygen-containing groups (hydroxymethyl, hydroxyethyl, and hydroxypropyl) were prepared via solvothermal method and ultrasonic impregnation. This method further improves the dispersion of the modifier and significantly enhances the catalytic activity in FTS. Carboxymethyl cellulose sodium salt-modified Fe-based catalyst inherently containing sodium promoter was used as the control sample. This study mainly focuses on the phase evolution and intermediate generation of hydroxyethyl-modified catalysts by combining multiple characterization techniques. Results reveal that the introduction of hydroxyethyl groups significantly accelerates iron carbide formation, suppresses excessive hydrogenation, and facilitates the coupling of *CHx species during the initial reaction pathway. 2 Chemicals and methods 2.1 Chemicals Iron trichloride hexahydrate [FeCl3·6 H2O], Sodium acetate [CH3COONa], Triton X-100 [C8H17C6H4(OCH2CH2)nOH, n = 5–10], Ethylene glycol [EG, C2H6O2], Diethylene glycol [DEG, C4H10O3], Hydroxymethyl cellulose [HMC, (C6H7O2(OH)3)n], Hydroxyethyl cellulose [HEC, (C2H6O2)n], Hydroxypropyl cellulose [HPC, (C15H28O8)n] and Carboxymethyl cellulose sodium salt [CMC, [C6H7O2(OH)x(OCH2COONa)y]n]. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Fe3O4 catalyst was prepared via solvent-thermal method [23]. Firstly, FeCl3·6 H2O (8 g) and triton X-100 (1 mL) were dissolved in EG (160 mL) and marked as solution A. CH3COONa (16 g) was dissolved in DEG (160 mL) and marked as solution B. Then, solutions A and B were mixed. The resulting solution was poured into a 500 mL stainless steel autoclave and heated at 200 ℃ for 10 h. The precipitate was washed by centrifugation to remove residual solvent. Finally, the Fe3O4 catalyst was obtained via vacuum drying overnight. Surface-modified Fe-based catalysts were synthesized via ultrasonic-assisted dip-coating. Specifically, 0.125 g of HMC, HEC, HPC or CMC was individually dispersed in 25 mL of deionized water to form homogeneous solutions. Concurrently, Fe₃O₄ powder (1 g) was dispersed in 25 mL of water. The two suspensions were then mixed under sonication for 4 h. The black suspension was dried overnight. Catalysts modified with different contents of HEC: Different masses of HEC powder were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water, followed by ultrasonic dissolution to form a uniform solution. 1 g of Fe3O4 powder was dispersed in 25 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the two solutions were mixed and sonicated continuously for 4 h. The resulting solution was vacuum-dried overnight at 60 ℃ to obtain catalysts modified with different contents of HEC. These catalysts were named as 1/4, 1/6, 1/8, 1/10, 1/15, and 1/20 based on the mass ratio of HEC to Fe3O4 powder. 2.3 Catalyst characterization methods XRD patterns of catalysts were collected on a Rigaku D/MAX 2200PC diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation. In situ XRD experiments were carried out on a Rigaku SmartLab equipped. The sample was loaded into an in situ cell and fed with syngas (CO:H2 = 1:2), the temperature was gradually increased to 280 ℃ under atmospheric pressure to detect the phase evolution of the synthesized catalyst. The textural properties of synthesized catalyst were measured by nitrogen physisorption on a Micromeritics NOVA2200e instrument. The morphology of synthesized catalyst were tested using scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy (SEM; SUPRA 55 SAPPHIRE, TEM; JEM-2100F). Contact angle (CA) was carried out on a POWEREACH JC2000C1 goniometer. TG-DSC analysis was tested on a SDT Q600 simultaneous thermal analyzer. Surface functional groups was carried out on spectroscopy a Bruker Tensor-27 Fourier Transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer. The reduction behavior of the samples was analyzed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. In brief, 50 mg of catalyst was pretreated with pure Ar at 280 ℃ for 2 h, and then the sample was cooled to 50 ℃ under an Ar atmosphere. Subsequently, the flowing gas was switched to 10 % H2 (30 mL·min−1) and heated to 800 ℃. CO-TPD procedure is as follows. The catalyst (50 mg) was with pure H2 flow at 280 ℃ for 2 h. Then, cooled to 50 ℃ in He flow and saturated with a 10 % CO (30 mL·min−1) for 2 h. Then, the sample was heated to 800 ℃ and TCD signal was recorded. The H2-TPD procedure is as follows. The catalyst (50 mg) was with pure H2 flow at 280 ℃ for 2 h. Then, the sample was cooled to 50 ℃ in Ar flow and saturated with a 10 % H2 (30 mL·min−1) for 2 h. The sample was heated to 800 ℃ and TCD signal was recorded. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurements were performed using an Agilent 7800 instrument from Agilent Technologies. The samples were digested with nitric acid. XPS analysis was conducted on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi instrument equipped with an Al Ka X-ray radiation source. 57Fe Mössbauer spectra (MES) of the sample were tested on a Topologic 500 A spectrometer, which was equipped with a 57Co (Rh) source operating in a constant acceleration mode at room temperature. In situ DRIFT spectra were tested on a Bruker TENSOR II spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance cell and a high-sensitivity MCT detector. Typically, the catalyst was reduced at 280 °C in syngas (CO: H2=1:2, 30 mL·min−1) for 6 h. Then, the gas atmosphere was switched to Ar with a flow (30 mL·min−1) for 4 h purging any accumulated species on the catalyst surface. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled to 50 °C. The feed syngas (CO: H2=1:2, 30 mL·min−1) was fed into the chamber, followed by raising the catalyst temperature from 50 to 280 °C and then holding it for 3 h. 2.4 Catalytic test CO hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a fixed-bed stainless steel continuous flow reactor. The synthesized catalyst of 0.2 mL loaded into the reactor. The synthesized sample was reduced at 280 ℃ for 8 h by syngas (H2: CO= 2:1) at GHSV = 1000 h−1 under 0.1 MPa. Subsequently, reaction pressure was maintained at 1.5 MPa and GHSV regulated to 5000 h−1 for catalyst CO hydrogenation performance evaluation. The products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014C) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The entire pipeline from the reactor to the GC was kept at least 180 ℃. The 13X molecular sieve and Porapak Q separation columns were connected to TCD for H2, CO2, CO and CH4 analysis, and the Pona column was connected to FID for hydrocarbons analysis. The selectivity for hydrocarbon products was calculated on a carbon basis, with the exception of CO2. The O/P value refers to the ratio of olefins to paraffins in the C2-C4 hydrocarbon fraction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structure The XRD characterization results of iron-based catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. For the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1a), the characteristic diffraction peaks were matched perfectly with the standard card (PDF# 19–0629) of Fe3O4 and with no detectable peaks observed [25]. This indicates that the crystal structure of Fe3O4 prepared by solvothermal method is intact and that the surface modification by CMC and HEC did not change the phase of Fe3O4 precursor, which is attributed to the modification process occurring only at the catalyst surface. The XRD results of the spent catalysts are shown that the unmodified Fe3O4 catalysts still show sharp and high-intensity Fe3O4 peaks at 2theta = 30.2 °, 35.6 °, etc. (PDF# 19–0629), and the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe5C2 were not observed [26]. In contrast, for the surface-modified Fe-based catalysts, the intensity of the Fe3O4 characteristic diffraction peaks decreased, and all of them showed obvious characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe5C2 at 2theta = 40 °-50 ° (PDF# 51–0997). This result suggests that the hydroxyethyl modification contributes to the formation of a stable Fe5C2 phase. To clarify the phase evolution mechanism during catalyst activation, in situ XRD was performed ( Fig. 2). Catalysts were heated to 280 °C under a CO/H2 (1:2) atmosphere and held isothermally. All samples initially exhibited a typical Fe3O4 phase (PDF# 19–0629). Notably, unmodified Fe3O4 retained the Fe3O4 phase without detectable iron carbide formation even after 300 min of reduction, which indicated that it was difficult to undergo the carburization during the reduction process. For surface-modified catalysts, the Fe3O4 peak intensity initially increased slightly but then decreased with reduction time, accompanied by distinct Fe5C2 diffraction signals at 2theta = 40 °-50 ° (PDF# 51–0997) [27]. Fe3O4/CMC showed obvious Fe5C2 peaks at 180 min, whereas Fe3O4/HEC displayed clear peaks as early as 90 min. These results demonstrate that hydroxyethyl modification shortens the carburization induction period and accelerates iron carbide formation, which is highly similar to the effect of alkali metal promoter [45]. 3.2 Textural properties The specific surface area and pore structure of the synthesized catalysts were systematically characterized using the N2 adsorption-desorption technique ( Table 1 and Fig. 3). The changes in the textural properties after modification with CMC were small. The changes in the pore volume and average pore diameter after surface modification of HEC were small, but the specific surface area was significantly reduced, which was attributed to the adsorption of hydrophilic HEC filling the pore channels of Fe3O4. The N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms of all catalysts showed IV-type features with H3-type hysteresis loops in the region of relative pressure P/P0 = 0.5–0.9 (Fig. 3a), indicating the presence of irregular mesoporous structures formed by the gaps between aggregated particles [28]. The adsorption of N₂ increased gently when P/P₀< 0.8, while the adsorption increased sharply when P/P₀> 0.8, confirming the existence of both mesoporous and macroporous hierarchical pore structures in the catalysts [29]. The BJH pore size distribution curve (Fig. 3b) reveals a broad distribution across all catalysts. The excellent pore size structure and surface area of the catalysts enhanced the diffusion of reactants and key intermediates, improved the catalytic activity and suppressed the secondary hydrogenation of olefins [30]. 3.3 Morphology of the catalyst In order to reveal the microstructural features of the synthesized catalysts, SEM and TEM were used for characterization ( Fig. 4). The unmodified Fe3O4 presented regular spherical particles with a rough surface and particle size roughly 200–300 nm. After surface modification with cellulose, SEM images showed that cellulose is attached to the surface of Fe3O4 and the structure of Fe3O4 is not damaged. With the preparation method of ultrasonic coating, the cellulose can be dispersed more evenly on the Fe3O4 surface. The inter-particle distance increased after the surface cellulose modification compared with the unmodified sample, which can effectively inhibit the agglomeration during the catalyst reaction process, thus improving the stability of the catalyst, and at the same time, it can shorten the residence time of the olefin product in the pores and effectively inhibit the hydrogenation side reaction [31]. As observed from the TEM images, the cellulose modification enriches the carbon and oxygen species on the catalyst surface. 3.4 Surface hydrophilic property To elucidate the effect of surface modification on the hydrophilicity of catalysts, the water contact angle (CA) was quantitatively characterized by sessile drop method ( Fig. 5). The CA of unmodified Fe3O4 was 60.6 °, which indicated that its surface was moderately hydrophilic. After modification by CMC, the CA of Fe3O4/CMC catalyst was reduced to 24.6 °, while that of Fe3O4/HEC catalyst was further reduced to 20.1 °, indicating a significant enhancement in hydrophilicity, which was attributed to the modulation of the surface functional groups (–OH, –COOH). The optimization of hydrophilicity regulates the product diffusion path via competitive adsorption of adsorbed water and olefin products on the catalyst surface, which promotes the desorption of olefins and inhibits their secondary hydrogenation in the active site [37]. 3.5 Surface functional groups and thermal stability TG-DSC was used to systematically investigate the thermal stability of the surface-modified catalysts in the FTS reaction ( Fig. 6). The Fe3O4/CMC and Fe3O4/HEC catalysts showed a typical two-stage weight loss, with a significant decrease in weight due to the breakage of the polymerization chain of the cellulose from 200 to 400 °C. The maximum weight-loss rate for Fe3O4/CMC occurred at 286 °C, which is attributed to the breakage of the C-O-C bond in CMC. The maximum weight-loss peak for Fe3O4/HEC was delayed to 305 °C, suggesting that the long-chain structure of the HEC is more thermally stable [32]. The peak decomposition temperatures of the modified catalysts were all higher than the FTS reaction temperature (280 °C). The weight loss of Fe3O4/CMC and Fe3O4/HEC catalyst samples was 5.21 % and 4.65 %, respectively, at the reaction temperature. The calculated mass of the cellulose coating on the Fe3O4 surface was 11 %, which indicated that the cellulose attached to the catalyst surface did not decompose completely. The surface functional groups of the catalysts were tested by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. In Fig. 7a, the broad peak near 3400 cm−1 was associated with the hydroxyl bending vibration of adsorbed H2O, and the 1640 cm−1 peak for Fe3O4/CMC was attributed to CO groups [33]. The Fe3O4/HEC catalyst exhibited a C-OH vibration at 1361 cm−1, and the 1064 cm−1 band corresponded to glycosidic bonds in celluloses [34]. A Fe-O stretching vibration at 589 cm−1 [23] confirmed cellulose modification of Fe3O4. In Fig. 7b, bands at 2922 and 2849 cm−1 were assigned to C-H and -CH2- stretching of organic residues [35]. Notably, cellulose characteristic peaks at 1640, 1064 and 1361 cm−1 remained, indicating surface group stability post-reaction. This finding corroborated the thermal stability of cellulose-modified catalysts, consistent with thermogravimetric results. 3.6 Reduction and chemisorption behaviors The reduction behavior of the catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR ( Fig. 8a). All catalysts showed two major reduction peaks: the low-temperature peak (200–400 °C) corresponded to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, the high-temperature peak (400–800 °C) corresponded to the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and Fe [36]. Due to the oxidation of sample surface, a small reduction peak appeared at 200–400 °C [37]. The reduction peak of the CMC-modified catalyst was shifted to lower temperatures, which could be attributed to the effect of the Na promoter. Notably, the high-temperature hydrogen-consumption peak of the HEC-modified catalyst shifted to a lower temperature, suggesting that the hydroxyethyl modification promoted the reduction of Fe. The effective adsorption of CO on the catalyst effectively improves the catalytic performance of CO hydrogenation. In order to elucidate the CO adsorption behavior of the synthesized catalysts, the catalysts were subjected to CO-TPD tests (Fig. 8b). All catalysts showed three broad desorption peaks from 300 °C to 800 °C. We observed that the Fe3O4/CMC and Fe3O4/HEC catalysts showed stronger CO desorption peaks from 500 °C to 800 °C. Fe3O4/CMC and Fe3O4/HEC catalysts were found to exhibit stronger CO desorption. This suggested that the surface modification of hydroxyethyl group enhanced the CO adsorption capacity, similar to the role played by alkali metal modification, and it has also been reported that the enhanced CO adsorption inhibits the adsorption of H2, thus suppressing the hydrogenation capacity [38]. This is in agreement with the H2-TPD results (Figure S1). The enhanced CO adsorption capacity promotes CO activation and the formation of iron carbide [30]. 3.7 Chemical state and surface analysis To reveal the surface chemical environment of the fresh catalyst, it was characterized by XPS ( Fig. 9, Table S1 and Table S2). As seen from the full spectrum in Fig. 9a, characteristic peaks of Fe, C and O were present in all catalysts. In Fig. 9b, the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks of unmodified Fe3O4 were located at 711.2 eV and 724.2 eV, respectively, and the presence of Fe3O4 was corroborated by a satellite peak at 719 eV [23,39]. The modified catalyst exhibited shifted peaks toward lower binding energies, indicating increased electron cloud density on surface Fe species. This suggests that the hydroxyethyl group facilitated electron transfer between the catalyst surface and the modifier, promoting Fe species reduction, in agreement with the H2-TPR results [40]. There are three peaks at 284.8, 286.1 and 288.7 eV in the C1s spectra (Fig. 9c), corresponding to graphitic carbon (C-C), C-O and O-CO in the synthesized catalysts, respectively [41,42]. Fig. 9d shows the O1s spectra of the synthesized catalysts. The peak near 530.1 eV, which belongs to lattice oxygen in Fe3O4, can be observed in all catalysts. The two peaks at 531.7 eV and 532.9 eV belong to C-O and O-CO, respectively [23]. The increase in the proportion of cellulose-related C-O and O-CO functional groups in modified catalysts suggests that cellulose has successfully modified the Fe3O4 surface (Table S2). 3.8 Mössbauer spectroscopy 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy characterized the spent catalyst ( Fig. 10), and quantitative phase analysis in Table S3 revealed the evolution of iron phases after the reaction. Results showed that unmodified spent Fe3O4 catalysts predominantly contained Fe3O4 (18.2 %) and Fe3+ (spm, 81.8 %), with no iron carbide detected. In contrast, surface-modified spent catalysts exhibited significant generation of χ-Fe5C2 active phase: Fe3O4/CMC contained 37.4 % χ-Fe5C2 and 62.6 % Fe3O4, while Fe3O4/HEC had 49.0 % χ-Fe5C2 and 51.0 % Fe3O4. The Fe5C2 content correlated with the catalyst high conversion and C5 + hydrocarbons selectivity, confirming that hydroxyethyl modification promoted iron carbide formation during syngas conversion by modulating electron transfer and interfacial stability [40,43]. 3.9 Catalytic performance and stability The catalytic performance and detailed carbon number distribution of the products for CO hydrogenation to olefins were summarized in Fig. 11, Fig. 12 and Figure S2), respectively. The unmodified Fe3O4 catalyst showed a CO conversion of 59.64 %, a C2-C4 olefin selectivity of only 23.66 % (O/P ratio of 1.15), a heavy hydrocarbon selectivity of 33.57 %, and higher selectivity for CH4 (22.16 %) and light alkanes (20.61 %). The catalytic performance of the HMC and HPC modified catalysts was slightly enhanced, indicating that the surface hydroxyl modification enhanced the catalytic performance, but the complexation of carbon-oxygen functional groups with appropriate carbon chains had a more significant effect. The Fe3O4/HEC catalysts showed the best performance, with selectivity of 41.36 % and 43.27 % for light olefins (C2-C4 =) and C5 + hydrocarbons (containing 68.2 % LAOs), while the selectivity of CH₄ and light alkanes (C2-C4 0) decreased to 10.68 % and 7.54 %, with an O/P ratio as high as 5.49. The performance of Fe3O4/CMC was also excellent due to the Na promoter. The hydroxyethyl-modified catalysts significantly promoted the formation of the χ-Fe5C2 active phase and facilitated the C-C coupling process by enhancing the CO chemisorption capacity. Meanwhile, the hydrophilic surface introduced by the modification and the presence of a hierarchical pore structure formed an efficient mass transfer channel, which effectively inhibited the hydrogenation reaction of olefins. The Fe3O4/HEC catalyst prepared in this work can achieve high CO conversion and high olefin selectivity under high space velocity (Table S5). The synthesized catalysts showed advantages in the stability of CO hydrogenation to olefins, with CO conversion and olefin selectivity remaining stable over a 14 h stream (Figure S4). Catalytic performance evaluation was conducted on catalysts modified with different contents of HEC to explore the optimal modification amount, as shown in Fig. 13. It was found that an excessive amount of HEC is unfavorable for olefin formation, which is attributed to the formation of a coating structure that inhibits olefin diffusion and promotes secondary hydrogenation reactions. An insufficient modification amount is also detrimental to olefin generation because the low content of HEC on the catalyst surface is not conducive to the formation of key intermediates. The optimal modification amount ranges from 1/10–1/8. 3.10 Structure-performance relationship In situ DRIFT spectra was employed to characterize the key intermediates on the catalyst. The catalyst was first treated under a CO/H2 atmosphere for 6 h to form in situ stable iron carbide active phase, followed by switching to an Ar atmosphere and heating to 280 °C for 4 h to remove surface carbonaceous deposits and other impurities. Subsequently, the gas atmosphere was switched back to syngas for temperature-programmed reaction. Spectroscopic analysis revealed that for all catalysts, the characteristic peaks at 2172 cm−1 and 2117 cm−1 were assigned to the R-branch and P-branch vibrations of gaseous CO [26]. The Fe3O4/HEC catalyst exhibited distinct peaks at 1515 cm−1 (-CC-), 2854 cm−1 (-CH-), 2929 cm−1 and 1442 cm−1 (-CH2-) [44]. In contrast, only weak -CH- and -CH2- signals were observed for the Fe3O4/CMC catalyst, and almost no characteristic peaks of intermediates were detected on the unmodified Fe3O4 catalyst. This confirms that hydroxyethyl modification significantly promotes the adsorption and stabilization of key intermediate species for olefin synthesis (e.g., *CH2, *CC). It is hypothesized that CHx* species play a crucial role in the formation of olefin products. The presence of hydroxyethyl groups promotes the accumulation of -CH2 intermediate species and facilitates the formation of CC bonds. Meanwhile, deep hydrogenation of *CHx intermediates is inhibited by the catalyst surface properties. Consequently, this endows the catalyst with high olefin selectivity and chain propagation capability [45]. This mechanism is considered to account for the high selectivity toward olefins and heavy hydrocarbons. 4 Conclusions Oxygen-containing group-modified Fe-based catalysts were synthesized by solvothermal and ultrasonic dip-coating methods and applied in CO hydrogenation. By combining in situ XRD, 57Fe Mössbauer spectra and in situ DRIFT spectra analysis techniques, the complex interplay between surface oxygen-containing groups and the active species was clearly elucidated. The introduction of hydroxyethyl groups significantly accelerated the formation of iron carbides. Hydrophilic surfaces and wide pore size distribution favor the desorption of olefins. Additionally, the key role of the *CHx intermediate is identified and highlighted, whose coverage is greatly altered by modulating its deep hydrogenation capability, making the C-C coupling process more competitive and improvement of olefin selectivity. This study provides a new surface modification method for Fe-based catalysts, which is different from the conventional method by alkali metal promoter modulation. coredata.dc:description: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a pivotal technology for sustainable production of chemicals from non-fossil resources. However, the design of catalysts to tailor product distribution, particularly to enhance olefin selectivity, remains an enduring challenge. Herein, we report an iron-based catalyst modified with oxygen-containing groups, Fe3O4/HEC (hydroxyethyl group-modified), which demonstrates extraordinary catalytic performance in FTS without any alkali metal promoters. This catalyst exhibits high activity, achieving 41.36 % light olefin (C2-C4 =) selectivity and an O/P ratio of 5.49. Meanwhile, the C5 + hydrocarbon selectivity reaches 40.38 % (with 68.2 % linear α-olefins). The modified catalyst promotes the formation of iron carbides and facilitates the coupling of *CHx to promote chain growth while suppressing secondary hydrogenation reactions, which is considered to account for the high selectivity toward olefins and heavy hydrocarbons.
